standard_metadata.standard_description: Use measures of center and measures of variability for numerical data from random samples to draw informal comparative inferences about two populations.

question.content: At the Olympic games, many events have several rounds of competition. One of these events is the men's $100$-meter backstroke.   The upper dot plot shows the times (in seconds) of the top $8$ finishers in the final round of the $2012$ Olympics. The lower dot plot shows the times of the same $8$ swimmers, but in the semifinal round.    **Which pieces of information can be gathered from these dot plots? (Remember that lower swim times are faster.) **

images.alt: A dot plot is divided into 2 parts labeled, Semifinal Round and Final Round. The horizontal axis is labeled, Time, in seconds, from 56 to 58, in increments of 0.10 second. The portion of the dot plot dedicated to Semifinal Round has dots above the following points; 56.7, 57.2, 57.3, 57.3, 57.4, 57.5, 57.7, and 57.8. The portion of the dot plot dedicated to Final Round has dots above the following points; 56, 56.6, 56.6, 57, 57.1, 57.2, 57.7, and 57.9.

options.content: The swimmers had faster times on average in the final round.
The times in the final round vary noticeably more than the times in the semifinal round.

hints.content: Now, let's consider the **second answer choice:**  > *The times in the final round vary noticeably more than the times in the semifinal round.*  We can see visually that the final round distribution is more spread out than the semifinal round distribution. We could calculate MAD or IQR from these displays, but we can see that the range of the final round distribution is larger.  So the times in the final round vary noticeably more than the times in the semifinal round.

Let's consider the **first answer choice:**  > *The swimmers had faster times on average in the final round.*  We don't have to calculate the mean values of each distribution because we can see visually that the center of the final round distribution is lower than the center of the semifinal round distribution.  Since lower times are faster,  we can say that the swimmers had faster times on average in the final round.
Select these answers:  >*The swimmers had faster times on average in the final round.*  >*The times in the final round vary noticeably more than the times in the semifinal round.*

question.content: The Baltimore Ravens won the American football championship in $2013$. In the same season, the Kansas City Chiefs had a record of $2$ wins and $14$ losses.   The dot plots below show the $40$-yard dash times (in seconds) of the defensive backs on each team's roster. Defensive backs mainly defend against passes, and the $40$-yard dash is the main measure of speed used in American football.      **Which pieces of information can be gathered from these dot plots? (Remember that lower $40$-yard dash times are faster.)  **

images.alt: A dot plot is divided into 2 parts labeled, Kansas City Chiefs and Baltimore Ravens. The horizontal axis is labeled, Time, in seconds, from 4.3 to 4.6, in increments of 0.01 second. The portion of the dot plot dedicated to Kansas City Chiefs has dots above the following points; 4.42, 4.43, 4.45, 4.47, 4.5, 4.52, and 4.56. The portion of the dot plot dedicated to Baltimore Ravens has dots above the following points; 4.3, 4.31, 4.34, 4.4, 4.44, 4.5, 4.52, 4.55, and 4.57.

options.content: The defensive backs on the Chiefs are faster on average.
The speed of the defensive backs on the Chiefs varies noticeably more than the speed of the defensive backs on the Ravens.

hints.content: Let's consider the **first answer choice:**  > *The defensive backs on the Chiefs are faster on average.*  We don't have to calculate the mean values of each distribution because we can see visually that the center of the Ravens distribution is lower than the center of the Chiefs distribution.  Since lower times are faster,  we can't say that the defensive backs on the Chiefs are faster on average.

Now, let's consider the **second answer choice:**  > *The speed of the defensive backs on the Chiefs varies noticeably more than the speed of the defensive backs on the Ravens.*  We can see visually that the Ravens distribution is more spread out than the Chiefs distribution. We could calculate MAD or IQR from these displays, but we can see that the range of the Ravens distribution is larger.  So we can't say that the speed of the defensive backs on the Chiefs varies noticeably more than the speed of the defensive backs on the Ravens.
Select this answer:  >*None of the above*

question.content: Before sending track and field athletes to the Olympics, the U.S. holds a qualifying meet.   The lower dot plot shows the times (in seconds) of the $8$ sprinters who competed in the final of the women's $100$-meter dash at the $2012$ Olympic games. The upper dot plot shows the times (in seconds) of the top $8$ sprinters at the U.S. qualifying meet for that event.    **Which pieces of information can be gathered from these dot plots? (Remember that lower sprint times are faster.) **

images.alt: A dot plot is divided into 2 parts labeled, Olympic final and U.S. Qualifier. The horizontal axis is labeled, Time, in seconds, from 10.7 to 11.2, in increments of 0.01 second. The portion of the dot plot dedicated to Olympic final has dots above the following points; 10.75, 10.78, 10.81, 10.85, 10.89, 10.94, 11, and 11.01. The portion of the dot plot dedicated to U.S. Qualifier has dots above the following points; 10.96, 11.07, 11.1, 11.1, 11.13, 11.14, 11.16, and 11.18.

options.content: The times in the Olympic final were faster on average than the top $8$ U.S. qualifier times.
All of the times in the Olympic final were faster than all of the top $8$ U.S. qualifier times.
The Olympic final times varied noticeably more than the times of the top $8$ U.S. qualifiers.

hints.content: Let's consider the **first answer choice:**  > *The times in the Olympic final were faster on average than the top $8$ U.S. qualifier times.*  We don't have to calculate the mean values of each distribution because we can see visually that the center of the Olympic final distribution is lower than the center of the U.S. qualifier distribution.  Since lower times are faster, we can say that times in the Olympic final were faster on average than the top $8$ U.S. qualifier times.

Now, let's consider the **second answer choice:**  > *All of the times in the Olympic final were faster than all of the top $8$ U.S. qualifier times.*  Since the distributions overlap, there were some times in the Olympic final distribution that were longer than some of the top $8$ U.S. qualifier times.  So we can't conclude that all of the times in the Olympic final were faster than all of the top $8$ U.S. qualifier times.

Lastly, let's consider the **third answer choice:**  >*The Olympic final times varied noticeably more than the times of the top $8$ U.S. qualifiers.*  We can see visually that the Olympic final distribution is more spread out than the U.S. qualifier distribution. We could calculate MAD or IQR from these displays, but we can see that the range of the Olympic final distribution is larger.  So the Olympic final times varied noticeably more than the times of the top $8$ U.S. qualifiers.

Select these answers:  > *The times in the Olympic final were faster on average than the top $8$ U.S. qualifier times.*  > *The Olympic final times varied noticeably more than the times of the top $8$ U.S. qualifiers.*

question.content: Before sending track and field athletes to the Olympics, the U.S. holds a qualifying meet.   The upper dot plot shows the distances (in meters) of the top $8$ shot putters in the preliminary round of the $2012$ Olympic games. The lower dot plot shows the top $8$ throwers in the shot put at the U.S. qualifying meet.    **Which pieces of information can be gathered from these dot plots?**

images.alt: A dot plot is divided into 2 parts labeled, U.S. Qualifier and Olympic Preliminary. The horizontal axis is labeled, Distance, in meters, from 19 to 21.5, in increments of 0.1 meter. The portion of the dot plot dedicated to U. S. Qualifier has dots above the following points; 19.15, 19.17, 19.5, 19.7, 19.8, 19.95, 20.25, and 21.22. The portion of the dot plot dedicated to Olympic Preliminary has dots above the following points; 20.43, 20.5, 20.55, 20.75, 20.8, 21.05, 21.15, and 21.45. All values estimated.

options.content: The top $8$ Olympic shot putters in the preliminary round threw farther on average than the top $8$ U.S qualifiers.
The distances of the top $8$ Olympic shot putters vary noticeably more than those of the top $8$ U.S. qualifiers.

hints.content: Let's consider the **first answer choice:**  > *The top $8$ Olympic shot putters in the preliminary round threw farther on average than the top $8$ U.S qualifiers.*  We don't have to calculate the mean values of each distribution because we can see visually that the center of the Olympic preliminary distribution is higher than the center of the U.S. qualifier distribution.  So we can say that the top $8$ Olympic shot putters in the preliminary round threw farther on average than the top $8$ U.S qualifiers.

Now, let's consider the **second answer choice:**  > *The distances of the top $8$ Olympic shot putters vary noticeably more than those of the top $8$ U.S. qualifiers.*  We can see visually that the U.S. qualifier distribution is more spread out than the Olympic preliminary distribution. We could calculate MAD or IQR from these displays, but we can see that the range of the U.S. qualifier distribution is larger.  So we can't conclude that the distances of the top $8$ Olympic shot putters vary noticeably more than those of the top $8$ U.S. qualifiers.
Select this answer:  >*The top $8$ Olympic shot putters in the preliminary round threw farther on average than the top $8$ U.S qualifiers.*

The times in the finals vary noticeably less than the times in the semifinals.

question.content: Minneapolis, Minnesota and Portland, Oregon have very similar latitudes. (Latitude measures how far north or south a place is, which in turn affects the temperature.)  The histograms below show the daily high temperatures (in degrees Celsius) that were recorded during January $2013$ in each city.           **Which pieces of information can be gathered from these histograms?**

images.alt: A histogram titled, Portland, plots Number of days, versus Temperature, in degrees Celsius, from negative 20 to 10, in increments of 3 degrees Celsius. Bar heights are approximately as follows. There are no bars between negative 20 and 1. From 1 to 4, 8. From 4 to 7, 12. From 7 to 10, 7. Greater than 10, 4.

A histogram titled, Minneapolis, plots Number of days, versus Temperature, in degrees Celsius, from negative 20 to 10, in increments of 3 degrees Celsius. Bar heights are approximately as follows. From negative 20 to negative 17, 1. From negative 17 to negative 14, 1. From negative 14 to negative 11, 3. From negative 11 to negative 8, 3. From negative 8 to negative 5, 5. From negative 5 to negative 2, 4. From negative 2 to 1, 5. From 1 to 4, 7. From 4 to 7, 2. From 7 to 10, 0. Greater than 10, 0.

options.content: On average, Minneapolis was colder during January.
On any given day, it was colder in Minneapolis than in Portland.
The daily high temperatures in January vary more noticeably in Minneapolis.

hints.content: Let's consider the **first answer choice:**  > *On average, Minneapolis was colder during January.*  We can't calculate the mean values of each distribution, but we can see visually that the center of the Minneapolis distribution is lower than the center of the Portland distribution.  So we can say that, on average, Minneapolis was colder during January.

Now, let's consider the **second answer choice:**  > *On any given day, it was colder in Minneapolis than in Portland.*  There are some temperatures in the Minneapolis distribution that are higher than some of the temperatures in the Portland distribution. This means it's possible that there was a day where it was hotter in Minneapolis than in Portland.  So we can't conclude that on any given day, it was colder in Minneapolis than in Portland.

Lastly, let's consider the **third answer choice:**  > *The daily high temperatures in January vary more noticeably in Minneapolis.*  We can see visually that the Minneapolis distribution is more spread out than the Portland distribution. We can't calculate MAD or IQR from these displays, but we can see that the range of the Minneapolis distribution is much larger.  So the daily high temperatures vary more noticeably in Minneapolis.
Select these answers:  >*On average, Minneapolis was colder during January.*  >*The daily high temperatures in January vary more noticeably in Minneapolis.*

question.content: The histograms below show the heights (in meters) of the tallest buildings in China and the United States.      **Which pieces of information can be gathered from these histograms?**

images.alt: A histogram titled, China plots Number of Buildings versus Height, in meters, from 240 and 540, in increments of 50. Bar heights are approximately as follows. From 240 to 290, 25. From 290 to 340, 7. From 340 to 390, 5. From 390 to 440, 3. From 440 to 490, 4. From 490 to 540, 2.

A histogram titled, United States plots Number of Buildings versus Height, in meters, from 240 and 540, in increments of 50. Bar heights are approximately as follows. From 240 to 290, 28. From 290 to 340, 15. From 340 to 390, 4. From 390 to 440, 1. From 440 to 490, 1. From 490 to 540, 0. Greater than 540, 1.

options.content: The United States has the tallest building of these two countries.
China has more buildings over $390$ meters tall.

hints.content: Let's consider the **first answer choice:**  > *The United States has the tallest building of these two countries.*  We can see that the tallest building in the United States is between $540$ and $590$ meters tall, and all of China's tallest buildings are below those heights.  So the United States has the tallest building of these two countries.

Now, let's consider the **second answer choice:**  > *China has more buildings over $390$ meters tall.*  We can count that China has $3+4+2=9$ buildings over $390$ meters tall, and the United States has $1+1+1=3$ buildings over $390$ meters tall.  So China has more buildings over $390$ meters tall.
Select these answers:  > *The U.S. has the tallest building of these two countries.*  > *China has more buildings over $390$ meters tall.*

question.content: Minneapolis, Minnesota and Portland, Oregon have very similar latitudes. (Latitude measures how far north or south a place is, which in turn affects the temperature.)  The histograms below show the daily high temperatures (in degrees Celsius) that were recorded during July $2013$ in each city.       **Which pieces of information can be gathered from these histograms?**

images.alt: A histogram titled, Portland, plots Number of days, versus Temperature, in degrees Celsius, from 15 to 33, in increments of 3 degrees Celsius. Bar heights are approximately as follows. There are no bars between 15 and 21. From 21 to 24, 3. From 24 to 27, 11. From 27 to 30, 6. From 30 to 33, 7. Greater than 33, 4.

A histogram titled, Minneapolis, plots Number of days, versus Temperature, in degrees Celsius, from 15 to 33, in increments of 3 degrees Celsius. Bar heights are approximately as follows. From 15 to 18, 1, From 18 to 21, 0. From 21 to 24, 2. From 24 to 27, 4. From 27 to 30, 6. From 30 to 33, 9. Greater than 33, 9.

options.content: It was warmer in Minneapolis every day.
Minneapolis had the coldest daily high temperature of these two cities.

hints.content: Let's consider the **first answer choice:**  > *It was warmer in Minneapolis every day.*  There are some temperatures in the Minneapolis distribution that are lower than some of the temperatures in the Portland distribution. This means it's possible that there was a day where it was colder in Minneapolis than in Portland.  So we can't conclude that it was warmer in Minneapolis every day.

Now, let's consider the **second answer choice:**  > *Minneapolis had the coldest daily high temperature of these two cities.*  We can see that the coldest daily high temperature in the Minneapolis distribution is between $15$ and $18^{\circ}\text{C}$, and all of the daily high temperatures in the Portland distribution are above those temperatures.  So Minneapolis had the coldest daily high temperature of these two cities.
Select this answer:  > *Minneapolis had the coldest daily high temperature of these two cities.*

question.content: People seem to like movies about comic book heroes.   The histograms below show the gross revenue (in hundreds of millions of dollars) of movies based on heroes from the two most popular comic book companies.        **Which pieces of information can be gathered from these histograms?**

images.alt: A histogram titled, DX Comics plots Number of Movies versus Revenue, from 1 to 6, in hundreds of millions of dollars. There is a gap in the bars between 3 and 4 hundred million dollars. Bar heights are approximately as follows. From 0 to 1, 11. From 1 to 2, 7. From 2 to 3, 4. From 3 to 4, 0. From 4 to 5, 1. From 5 to 6, 1.

A histogram titled, Marble Comics plots Number of Movies versus Revenue, from 1 to 6, in hundreds of millions of dollars. There is a gap in the bars between 5 and 6 hundred million dollars. Bar heights are approximately as follows. From 0 to 1, 7. From 1 to 2, 15. From 2 to 3, 3. From 3 to 4, 4. From 4 to 5, 2. From 5 to 6, 0. Over 6, 1.

options.content: Movies based on Marble heroes bring in more money on average.
All Marble movies bring in more money than all DX movies.
The amount earned by DX movies varies much more than the amount earned by Marble movies.

hints.content: Now, let's consider the **second answer choice:**  > *All Marble movies bring in more money than all DX movies.*  There are some movies in the Marble distribution that brought in less money than some of the movies in the DX distribution.  So we can't conclude that all Marble movies bring in more money than all DX movies.

Let's consider the **first answer choice:**  > *Movies based on Marble heroes bring in more money on average.*  We can't calculate the mean values of each distribution, but we can see visually that the center of the Marble distribution is higher than the center of the DX distribution.  So we can say that movies based on Marble heroes bring in more money on average.

Lastly, let's consider the **third answer choice:**  > *The amount earned by DX movies varies much more than the amount earned by Marble movies.*  We can see visually that the Marble distribution is more spread out than the DX distribution. We can't calculate MAD or IQR from these displays, but we can see that the range of the Marble distribution is larger.  So we can't conclude that the amount earned by DX movies varies much more than the amount earned by Marble movies.
Select this answer:  >*Movies based on Marble heroes bring in more money on average.*

question.content: Before sending track and field athletes to the Olympics, the U.S. holds a qualifying meet.   The upper box plot shows the top $12$ men's long jumpers at the U.S. qualifying meet. The lower box plot shows the distances (in meters) achieved in the men's long jump at the $2012$ Olympic games.    **Which pieces of information can be gathered from these box plots?**

images.alt: 2 horizontal boxplots titled U.S. Qualifier and Olympics are graphed on the same horizontal axis, labeled Distance, in meters. The boxplot titled U.S. Qualifier has a left whisker which extends from 7.68 to 7.7. The box extends from 7.7 to 7.89 and is divided into 2 parts by a vertical line segment at 7.74. The right whisker extends from 7.9 to 7.99. The boxplot titled Olympics has a left whisker which extends from 7.7 to 7.83. The box extends from 7.83 to 8.12 and is divided into 2 parts by a vertical line segment at 8.04. The right whisker extends from 8.12 to 8.31. All values estimated.

options.content: The Olympic jumps were farther on average than the U.S. qualifier jumps.
All of the Olympic jumps were farther than all of the U.S. qualifier jumps.
The Olympic jumps vary noticeably more than the U.S. qualifier jumps.

hints.content: Let's consider the **first answer choice:**  > *The Olympic jumps were farther on average than the U.S. qualifier jumps.*  We can't calculate the mean values of each distribution, but we can see visually that the center of the Olympics distribution is higher than the center of the U.S. qualifier distribution.  So we can say that the Olympic jumps were farther on average than the U.S. qualifier jumps.

Now, let's consider the **second answer choice:**  > *All of the Olympic jumps were farther than all of the U.S. qualifier jumps.*  Since the distributions overlap, there are some jumps in the U.S. qualifier distribution that are larger than some of the jumps in the Olympic distribution.  So we can't conclude that all of the Olympic jumps were farther than all of the U.S. qualifier jumps.

Lastly, let's consider the **third answer choice:**  > *The Olympic jumps vary noticeably more than the U.S. qualifier jumps.*  We can see visually that the Olympics distribution is more spread out than the U.S. qualifier distribution. We can't calculate MAD from these displays, but we can see that the IQR and range of the Olympics distribution is much larger.  So the Olympic jumps vary noticeably more than the U.S. qualifier jumps.
Select these answers:  >*The Olympic jumps were farther on average than U.S. qualifier jumps.*  >*The Olympic jumps vary noticeably more than the U.S. qualifier jumps.*

question.content: Macaws are tropical birds that can live a very long time. The box plots below show the life spans (in years) of a random sample of Macaws that lived in captivity and a random sample that lived in the wild.    **Which pieces of information can be gathered from these box plots?**

images.alt: 2 horizontal boxplots titled Captivity and Wild are graphed on the same horizontal axis, labeled Life Span, in years. The boxplot, titled Captivity, has a left whisker which extends from 66 to 73. The box extends from 73 to 80 and is divided into 2 parts by a vertical line segment at 77. The right whisker extends from 80 to 84. The second boxplot, titled Wild, has a left whisker which extends from 32 to 48. The box extends from 48 to 62 and is divided into 2 parts by a vertical line segment at 54. The right whisker extends from 62 to 77. All values estimated.

options.content: On average, life spans were longer for the Macaws in the wild.
The life spans for all of the Macaws in captivity were longer than all of those in the wild.
The life spans for the Macaws in the wild varied noticeably more than those in captivity.

hints.content: Let's consider the **first answer choice:**  > *On average, life spans were longer for the Macaws in the wild.*  We can't calculate the mean values of each distribution, but we can see visually that the center of the captivity distribution is higher than the center of the wild distribution.  So we can't say that life spans were longer on average for the Macaws in the wild.

Now, let's consider the **second answer choice:**  > *The life spans for all of the Macaws in captivity were longer than all of those in the wild.*  Since the distributions overlap, there are some Macaws in the wild distribution that had longer life spans than some of the Macaws in the captivity distribution.  So we can't conclude that the life spans for all of the Macaws in captivity were longer than all of those in the wild.

Lastly, let's consider the **third answer choice:**  > *The life spans for the Macaws in the wild varied noticeably more than those in captivity.*  We can see visually that the wild distribution is more spread out than the captivity distribution. We can't calculate MAD from these displays, but we can see that the IQR and range of the wild distribution is much larger.  So the life spans for the Macaws in the wild varied noticeably more than those in captivity.
Select this answer:  >*The life spans for the Macaws in the wild varied noticeably more than those in captivity.*

options.content: The distances in the Olympic final were farther on average.
The distances in the Olympic final were all greater than the U.S. qualifier distances.
The distances in the Olympic final varied noticeably more than the U.S qualifier distances.

hints.content: Let's consider the **first answer choice:**  > *The distances in the Olympic final were farther on average.*  We can't calculate the mean values of each distribution, but we can see visually that the center of the Olympic final distribution is higher than the center of the U.S. qualifier distribution.  So we can say that the distances in the Olympic final were farther on average.

Now, let's consider the **second answer choice:**  > *The distances in the Olympic final were all greater than the U.S. qualifier distances.*  Since the distributions overlap, there are some distances in the Olympic final distribution that are less than some of the distances in the U.S. qualifier distribution.  So we can't conclude that the distances in the Olympic final were all greater than the U.S. qualifier distances.

So we can't say that the distances in the Olympic final varied noticeably more than the U.S qualifier distances.
Select this answer:  >*The distances in the Olympic final were farther on average.*

question.content: The box plots below show the heights (in centimeters) of the players on the University of Maryland women's basketball and field hockey teams.        **Which pieces of information can be gathered from these box plots?**

images.alt: 2 horizontal boxplots titled Basketball Team and Field Hockey Team are graphed on the same horizontal axis, labeled height, in centimeters. The boxplot titled Basketball Team has a left whisker which extends from 165 to 173. The box extends from 173 to 191 and is divided into 2 parts by a vertical line segment at 188. The right whisker extends from 191 to 203. The boxplot titled Field Hockey Team has a left whisker which extends from 157 to 160. The box extends from 160 to 168 and is divided into 2 parts by a vertical line segment at 163. The right whisker extends from 168 to 178. All values estimated.

options.content: The basketball players are taller on average.
The heights of the basketball players vary noticeably more than those of the field hockey team.

hints.content: Let's consider the **first answer choice:**  > *The basketball players are taller on average.*  We can't calculate the mean values of each distribution, but we can see visually that the center of the basketball team distribution is higher than the center of the field hockey team distribution.  So we can say that the basketball players are taller on average.

Now, let's consider the **second answer choice:**  > *The heights of the basketball players vary noticeably more than those of the field hockey team.*  We can see visually that the basketball team distribution is more spread out than the field hockey team distribution. We can't calculate MAD from these displays, but we can see that the IQR and range of the basketball team distribution is much larger.  So we can say that the heights of the basketball players vary noticeably more than those of the field hockey team.
Select these answers:  >*The basketball players are taller on average.*  >*The heights of the basketball players vary noticeably more than those of the field hockey team.*
